messageBody:
Ernst Reissner wrote:

> I have no mission and noone needs to beleave me.
> What i want to express is:
> "No you can't, and you shouldn't"
> means: you cannot discuss about this.
> I think: Of course you can. And the discussion shows people feel some need.
> Would you agree so far?

No. I definitely did not mean to say "you cannot discuss about this". I
invite you to consider 3 other interpretations for "No you can't, and
you shouldn't" that do not means "you cannot discuss about this". (This
is a classic exercise from the work of Jerry Weinberg.)

> "...becausee those are 3 different tests "
> hm,... these ARE 3 different tests because you make them 3 different tests.

No, they are 3 different tests because a test consists of "given this
precondition, if I perform that action, I expect these results". Read
any book on TDD, programmer testing or JUnit for references.

> What i wanted to point out is:
> this is a design decision.
> And i had the impression you negate this.

It is absolutely a design decision. JUnit does not support multiple
failing assertions per test in part because it is simpler to stop the
test when it first fails, and in part to encourage strong isolation of
tests from each other. This has been part of the TDD literature for
years--Kent Beck, Test-Driven Development: By Example, in particular.

> hope i didn't hurt you.

You did, but I can recover from it. :) I appreciate your willingness to
continue the conversation.
